I rarely agree with Mr. Douthat, but in this case I believe he is 100% right. Don't confuse the Euro currency with the EU (European Union) free trade area. By giving up their own currency and adopting the Euro, Greece, Spain, Italy, Portugal, Ireland and others effectively began borrowing in a foreign currency over which they had no control. -- The Euro is in effect the Deutsch Mark, and run by Germany for the benefit of Germans. --

And what is good for Germany is not necessarily good for its neighbors. For years interests aligned, but recently they have diverged dramatically. Much of the problem in Europe can be laid at the feet of Germany who insist on fiscal and monetary austerity since Germans want to hold onto the financial gains over the past decade or more. Money made by providing loans to the much of Europe so the Greeks, Spanish, Italians and others could buy German products.

It is in the interest of everyone except Germany to have healthy inflation of 4% - 6% since inflation reduces the real burden of debt. Instead, Germany has insisted on Austerity which has caused a deflationary spiral and made those loans even larger in real terms. So if Germany won't do what is right for Europe, then either Germany should be kicked out of the Euro, or everyone else needs to abandon the Euro. Then they would be free to pursue a rational course of mild/healthy inflation and get everyone back to work.

"But right now, the E.U. project isn’t advancing democracy, liberalism and human rights."

Actually, WP, those depression levels of unemployment and the even more disastrous levels among younger workers relate more directly to a global supply glut--enormous industrial over-capacity which has rendered so many factories and workers "redundant." China's entry into the WTO vastly exacerbated the over-production crisis already existing among the US, Japan, and Germany. Marxists once referred to such supply glut as crises of "under-consumption," putting the onus on insufficient demand, since poorly paid workers couldn't afford all the goods that increasingly productive technologies could produce. Ecologically that characterization no longer makes sense.

Capitalist relations of production may fetter the potential growth of global GDP, but if it didn't, environmental catastrophe would--and will still if we don't expeditiously plot a new course. Nonetheless, we're left with a jobs crisis and festering social catastrophe in nations where more than half the young can't find productive employment. Rather than engage in polemics against "heartless" austerians or "unrealistic" anti-austerians, we'd be better served pursuing ideas advanced in such books as Tim Jackson's "Prosperity without Growth," Bill Kibben's "Deep Economy," or David Korten's "Agenda for a New Economy." And to recall that Lord Keynes himself counseled us to minimize "free trade"--and to be vigilant in preventing the accumulation of imbalances which have so distorted and destabilized the global economy.

Mr. Douthat speaks of the "mass unemployment unseen in the history of modern Europe, and mass youth unemployment that is worse still" as if it just fell out of the sky. But of course it didn't. Instead, that mass unemployment is the result of the fact that Germany and the rest of the EU has been forcing on nation's such as Greece, Ireland, Spain, etc. a cruel form of austerity that has driven those countries into a deeper and deeper economic depression.

Why does Mr. Douthat leave that detail out? Because such austerity is exactly what conservatives like him hope to impose on the US. Fortunately, we have managed to largely avoid such austerity here in the US. In the wake of the economic collapse of 2008, President Obama and the Democrats managed to get a significant stimulus bill passed. And since then, the Administration has used every tool it could find (such as payroll tax cuts and unemployment benefit extensions) to continue some stimulus. The stimulus has been far from enough, largely because of GOP obstructionism, but our economy is slowly recovering, while Europe's is in a spiraling disaster thanks to austerity.

In Europe, the question is how much havoc will the disastrous austerity path inflict. Here in the US, the question is how to we rescind the sequester and ensure that conservatives don't succeed in their efforts to take us down the failed path of austerity.

Cost Estimation of Uranium Recovery from Seawater with System of Braid Type Adsorbent

Journal Title;Transactions of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan

"Abstract; Uranium cost in the annual collection of 1,200t-U from seawater was evaluated by using the recovery system of braid type adsorbents synthesized by radiation-induced graft polymerization. The total cost was calculated by summating those in the processes of adsorbent production, uranium recovery, and elution and purification. When the adsorbent performance increased from 2g-U/kg-adsorbent (ad) to 6g-U/kg-ad, the cost of each process decreased in the same way. The increment of adsorbent durability of 6 times to 60 times reduced the process cost of adsorbent production especially. In the current state of 2g-U/kg-ad and 6 times usage of adsorbent, the uranium from seawater cost 90,000yen/kg-U. The uranium cost becomes 25,000yen/kg-U in the promising performance of 4g-U/kg-ad and 18 times usage of adsorbent. (author abst.)"
